subject: Re: [junit] black box or white box?

messageBody:
Daniel Barclay wrote:
> Isn't part of the difference that for black box testing, you don't know
> how it works, just what it does, so you can only test based on interesting
> case and boundary conditions on the inputs. In white box testing, you
> know how it works, so you can test based on knowing that different inputs
> get processing differently.

Yes, that is part of the difference. Like I said it was a _quick_
summary.

>
> For example, for some index class, if you know it uses a linear list up
> to 5 items and then a hash table, choosing to test with 4 items to test
> the list case and also test with 5 items to test the hash table case is
> white box testing.

Yes. That is an example of whitebox testing.

------------------------------

My viewpoint:

I focus on component development. Components differ from objects in two
key areas: they live in a container, and all their contracts are
specified by an interface. The container controls how they live and
die, and which implementation of the component is used. Quick
analogy:

Imagine buying a radio. We all know how a radio works. It's interface
is the same no matter where you go--you have a control to change the
station and a control to change the volume. There are several models
of the radio, and in a store, there are many instances of each model.

The Component is the radio. It is composed of an interface (separate
from the actual implementation of the component), and its implementation
(the model of radio). A container picks which model to give you,
creates the instance, and lets you use it.

You can only really do black box testing in this type of environment.
You have the advantage of knowing what the component does. You don't
know how it does it--and from the perspective of using the component
you don't care.

I have created a test harness using JUnit for my components, so that I
can test several component types with one TestCase. It's a beautiful
thing.

Now, If I tried to write a white-box test on my component, I run into
some serious setbacks. That white-box (or micro test) is tied to the
component implementation. I cannot reuse that test on another
implementation of the same component interface. That is a serious
drawback to me.

--------------------------------

Different tools for different fools:

JUnit is designed for blackbox testing. That is how it should be used.
The new JDK 1.4 assertion facilities are for whitebox testing. That is
how they should be used.
